Department of Chemical Engineering and Analytical Science School of Engineering The University of Manchester Manchester M13 9PL United Kingdom Graphical abstract Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) provides a promising route for upgrading biomass-derived fatty acids to alkanes, which are potential biofuels (e.g. jet fuel (C8–C16) and diesel (C12–C22)) that could reduce our reliance on unsustainable fossil fuels. Currently, catalytic HDO, conducted over catalysts such as molybdenum disulfide, necessitates harsh operating conditions (>300 °C) which is both environmentally and economically unsustainable and promotes unwanted side reactions, e.g. cracking, which compromises product selectivity. Accordingly, the development of novel catalysts, which enable efficient and sustainable HDO, under milder operating conditions, and their translation from lab bench to large-scale production are highly desired. This review discusses the recent development of heterogeneous catalysts for HDO (including reaction pathways, mechanisms, and side reactions) and explores design strategies for the development of new multifunctional catalysts with potential to enable future development of HDO processes under mild conditions. In particular, we consider the sequential cascade transformation of fatty acids into fatty alcohols (via hydrodeoxygenation) and then hydrocarbons (via dehydration and hydrogenation), which requires the coupling of different but complementary catalytic sites, as an attractive alternative mild HDO strategy. Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Biofuel Fatty acids Noble metal catalysts Zeolites 1 Introduction The demand for petroleum based transportation fuels is predicted to increase by 1.3 % per annum, which potentially represents a carbon emission enhancement of 80 % from 2007 levels by 2030 [1]. Biofuels represent promising alternatives to fossil fuels, including petroleum and natural gas, with reduced environmental impact and carbon footprints. They are produced from renewable biomass, primarily vegetable oils [2,3], animal fats [1,3] and lignocellulose [3,4], and are derived from ecosphere carbon reserves, in contrast to fossil fuels which are locked within the lithosphere. As a result, biofuels also bestow a circular economy into fuel production, via the carbon cycle, thus abating increasing net carbon levels from the use of fossil fuel reserves for current transportation fuels [5]. Traditional biofuels (first-generation) are based on edible feedstocks, including soybean oil, rapeseed oil and sunflower oil, which due to their high oil content were initially considered as ideal candidates for biodiesel production [6,7]. However, such first-generation feedstocks compete with food production, which given that approximately 10 % of the global population are chronically malnourished, this has given rise to considerable debate over the ethics of their use [8]. Second-generation biofuels, based on non-edible feedstocks such as oils from drought-tolerant plants (include species that can thrive on low fertile soils unsuitable for farming), used cooking oils, and waste animal fats/greases, are desirable options as prospective feedstocks. Furthermore, processing these offers routes to value-added products, including pathways for waste valorisation, and can thus impart economic benefit without significantly impacting food supply [9]. Triglycerides represent the major components of both plant oils and animal fats. To obtain biofuels with comparable carbon content to petroleum-based fuels, C8–C16 for aviation fuels and C12–C22 for diesel, triglycerides can be dissociated into their constituent free fatty acids and backbone (glycerol or propane depending on processing pathway). Common processes to realise this include saponification-neutralisation (Eq.1a), transesterification-hydrolysis (Eq.1b) and direct hydrogenolysis (Eq.1c) [10,11]. Saponification-neutralisation is widely used to release fatty acids from triglycerides, due to the cheap reactants (e.g. NaOH and HCl) and mild conditions (∼60 °C) [12,13]. Fatty acids methyl esters (FAMEs) can be utilised directly as biodiesel but are unsuitable as aviation fuels due to poor cold flow properties and storage stability [14]. These are obtained via transesterification with methanol (∼60 °C under basic conditions) [15] and can undergo further reactions with water to yield the fatty acid. Hydrogenolysis represents a third pathway to fatty acids [8]. Even though hydrogenolysis necessitates harsher conditions (>260 °C), it can result in cooperative one-pot hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) to yield high-valued biofuels [16]. The presence of carboxyl and alkenyl moieties within fatty acids imparts high corrosivity and poor stability [17], and thus HDO (Eq. 2) is essential to obtaining stable alkanes [18]. Furthermore, HDO can ensure fuel compatibility with existing supply infrastructure and engines. Therefore it has been considered a viable route to produce biofuels for aviation, public transportation, and road haulage industries [19–21]. HDO reactions are commonly accompanied by direct decarboxylation (DCO2) or decarbonylation (DCO) side-reactions, as shown in Eqs. 3 and 4, respectively [18]. The two side-reactions (DCOx) likewise produce alkanes, albeit with a decrease in carbon chain length of one relative to HDO, and while hydrogen consumption is lessened, it leads to CO/CO2 as the by-product instead of H2O. Therefore, DCOx represents lower atom economy with regard to C within the desired product. Esterification (Eq. 5) can also occur, especially at low to medium acid conversion levels. However, esters can undergo further reactions to yield either their constituent acid and alcohol, via hydrogenolysis or hydrolysis, or alkanes via direct HDO. An ester sink in this pathway is only common where HDO proceeded over catalysts with weak acidity and under mild conditions. Irreversible hydrocracking (Eq. 6) can also arise, leading to unwanted out of fuel specification hydrocarbon by-products. Finally, while direct HDO of triglycerides to alkene has been demonstrated, studies employing fatty acids, as model compounds, are more common within the literature due to higher reaction rate. Liu et al. compared the HDO activity of a Pd/0.4SiW-SiO2-B catalyst for stearic acid and methyl stearate (as simple ester) at 180 °C, which showed acid and ester conversions of 88 % and 46 % respectively [22]. Furthermore, they used the same catalysts for HDO of soybean oil at 200 °C with only 58 % conversion at 6 h. Supported mixed metal sulphides, such as NiW/SiO2-Al2O3, NiMo/Al2O3 or CoMo/Al2O3 [23,24] have been put forward as likely HDO catalysts, in part due to their use in hydroprocessing in petroleum refining [25]. The preference for mixed metals reflects their greater stability over monometallic equivalents. However, sulphide catalysts require co-feeding of hydrogen sulphide (H2S) or dimethyl disulphide (DMDS) to maintain the catalytic activity [26], which can lead to final product contamination. To reduce the dependence on sulphide based materials, nitride and carbide based catalysts were proposed as alternatives [27–29]. The incorporation of carbon or nitrogen within the crystal structure induces an increase in the lattice parameter and d-electron density in both Mo and W, which endows catalytic activity comparable with sulphide-based systems [27]. However, these catalysts require harsh reaction conditions to activate HDO, including high temperatures > 340 °C and pressures > 30 bar, which are energy-intensive and increase the risk associated with the reaction. Furthermore, high operating temperatures can result in thermal decomposition and coking, which generates undesired short-chain gaseous hydrocarbons and accelerates catalyst deactivation, respectively [2,23,24,27,30]. In order to reduce the operation cost and improve the production of biofuels, the development of active and selective catalysts for HDO under mild conditions is key. Noble metals catalysts, such as Pd [31], Pt [32] and Ru [33], are acknowledged for their capacity in activating H2 at relatively low temperatures, offering opportunities for catalytic HDO under milder processing conditions. Their advantages can be summarised as (i) high activity at moderate temperatures (<300 °C), (ii) no requirements for sulphur co-feeding, and (iii) flexible catalyst design through tailoring of the physicochemical properties of the supports and active sites, which lead improved efficiency and reduced environmental impact, and give control over reaction routes and conditions [34]. As shown in Fig. 1 , the number of publications for noble metal catalysed HDO of fatty acid has significantly increased over the last five years. However, supported noble metal catalysts are hindered economically due to their high costs. Furthermore, over current supported noble metal catalysts (e.g. on alumina or microporous zeolite) at ≤270 °C, decarboxylation (DCO2) is likely [35]. More recent studies into novel bi-/multi-functional catalysts have demonstrated opportunities for optimizing supported noble metal catalysts, which can enable one-pot HDO for biofuel production with the increased selectivity towards desired hydrocarbons under milder conditions. Shimizu and co-workers introduced Lewis acidity, through the incorporation of Nb2O5 or MoOx, either as the catalyst support or as the dopant to the Pt active sites [36,37]. In both cases, the Lewis acidity facilitates the conversion of fatty acids into fatty alcohols, esters and/or alkanes, as well as limiting DCOx, at a mild process temperature of 200 °C. MoOx doped Pt showed improved alkane production, relative to the Pt supported on the Nb2O5 catalyst, attributed to the higher hydrogenation activity [36,37]. The presence of Lewis acid sites can activate the carbonyl group (electron-rich) in the fatty acids and facilitate reactant adsorption, which may promote the HDO activity at reduced temperatures. Similarly, Darbha et al. reported a MoOx doped Pt catalyst, in which ZrO2 was used as an alternative to TiO2 as the support, and showed the enhanced electron density at the Pt surface due to the presence of MoOx, indicating a direct interaction between the two, which induced more efficient catalytic HDO at 200 °C [19]. A further reduction in HDO temperature has been demonstrated over a bimetallic catalyst supported on graphite, in which Pd is coupled with Re (i.e. Pd-Re/C) [38], with subtle changes in reaction temperature proving critical to the final product. Reactions at 130 °C yielded fatty alcohols, an intermediate HDO product, whereas at 160 °C full HDO was achieved with the alkane product dominating. The author suggested a two-step reduction pathway, with the complete acid reduction to the alcohol occurring prior to significant alkene formation. The reaction mixture also included the addition of 4A molecular sieve as the desiccant. Its addition could well further enhance the process efficiency by shifting equilibriums and overcoming potential reverse reactions. Alternatively, 4A molecular sieve has also demonstrated capacity for ethanol dehydration to ethylene, however, this occurred at a significantly higher temperature of 270 °C [39]. An alternative approach to fatty acid HDO to alkanes is to consider each chemical transformation step individually and as part of a multi-step cascade process, as shown in Scheme 1 . As such, each active species can be assessed separately and precisely tuned for its step in the cascade system. With the philosophy in mind, the coupling of a Pd based hydrogenation catalyst and an acid zeolite catalyst for dehydration has shown to work cooperatively during acid HDO to alkanes [40]. This review will span the range of HDO catalytic materials to elucidate the function of different catalyst sites, promotors and supports, and their limitations, understand the interactions of the substrate and different active sites, and investigate the mechanism(s) of HDO of different catalytic materials. The insight from this critical review will be discussed to suggest future research directions for developing HDO catalysts designed explicitly with a cascade process in mind. In particular, systems, in which more than one class of active species are present within a single catalyst, i.e. bi/multifunctional catalysts, are explicitly reviewed. Although reviews related to HDO have been previously conducted [3,21,41], a designated review is necessary to guide the design and development of the new multifunctional low-temperature HDO cascade catalysts for effective HDO. 2 Traditional HDO catalysts 2.1 Sulphide catalysts Since the 1930s, sulphide based catalysts have been widely applied in industrial hydrofining processes, making them the most widely studied catalysts for hydrodesulfurisation (HDS), hydrodenitrogenation (HDN) and HDO [42]. 2-ethylphenol has been used to study the mechanism of HDO over MoS2, as shown in Fig. 2 [41,43]. Initial catalysts activation occurs via hydrogen extraction of S from the sulphide framework to form vacancy sites, these bind 2-ethylphenol through its oxygen atom. Subsequent protonation of the adsorbate generates a carbocation and induces the direct CO bond cleavage, leading to the elimination of oxygen (as water) and the deoxygenated compound. Ni or Co are commonly employed as dopants in MoS2 catalysts, especially for fatty acid HDO, due to their capacity for electron donation, which weakens the Mo-S bond and enhances sulphur vacancy site formation [43]. As shown in Table 1 , the acidity of catalyst supports can impact on HDO selectivity. Kubicka et al. prepared Co-Mo catalysts by loading 15 wt.% Mo onto ordered mesoporous alumina (OMA) and MCM-41 (mesoporous silica), followed by impregnating with 3 wt.% Co [44]. Sulfiding of the catalyst was carried out at 320 °C using a DMDS isooctane solution, prior to HDO of rapeseed oil (consisting of C16 and C18 fatty acids). At 310 °C and 70 bar H2, conversion over the two catalysts was comparable, being ∼100 % for Co-Mo@OMA and ∼95 % for Co-Mo@MCM-41. However, Co-Mo@OMA showed a significantly superior octadecane selectivity of about 93 %, whilst Co-Mo@MCM-41 achieved only a modest 66 % selectivity to C18 alkane, revealing the importance of the support. With OMA promoting the dehydration of the fatty alcohol intermediate. Conversely, the less acidic MCM-41 support promoted notable decarbonylation chemistry, which led to heptadecane formation [45]. Similar findings were also reported by Sivasanker et al. [46]. Although Brønsted acidity can impede DCOx pathways, strong acidity (e.g. zeolites) can result in hydrocracking, producing short-chain hydrocarbons, which are out of the desired range for biofuels [2]. Chen et al. prepared sulfided Ni-Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts for HDO of soybean oil at 380 °C and 30 bar H2 [2]. Once again, the acidic property of the zeolite support showed a significant effect on the selectivity of HDO, with ∼80 % selectivity to C16–C18 over Ni-Mo@Na-ZSM-5 (zeolites present in the Na form), whilst selectivity shift to the C4–C8 range (90 %) over the Ni-Mo site supported on the protonated acidic zeolite (Ni-Mo@H-ZSM-5). In addition to catalysts support acidity, short-chain hydrocarbons are also prone to form during HDO at excessively high temperatures via thermal decomposition. Simacek et al. conducted HDO of rapeseed oil under 70 bar of H2 using commercial sulphide catalysts supported on alumina [16]. With an increase of reaction temperature from 260 °C to 340 °C, C15–C18 products in liquid phase decreased from 49.6 %–42.2 %. Considering the current scale of biofuels production, which provided 9.7 × 106 GJ d−1 of energy in 2016, and expected to increase to account for 16 % of transportation demand in 2040 (4.6 × 107 GJ d−1) [47], a 7.4 % yield loss is significant. However, the high temperature of 340 °C did promote isomerisation reactions, resulting in >20 % selectivity to C16–C18 iso-alkanes, whilst, at 260 °C, iso-alkanes accounted for only 5 % of the products. The benefit of iso-alkanes lie in their lower melting points, which could be beneficial in the production of biofuels for use in winter or at high-altitude. Accordingly, when sulphide catalysts are employed for HDO of fatty acids, the acidity of the catalyst support needs to be tuned to suppress both DCOx and hydrocracking. Meanwhile, the reaction temperature also needs to be regulated to mitigate hydrocracking, however promoting alkane isomerisation may be of benefit. Catalysts stability is another critical parameter, with Jensen and co-workers reporting that sulphide based catalysts can transform into oxides during the deoxygenation step, which renders them inactive towards HDO. H2S or DMDS are therefore commonly co-fed to alleviate this issue, via regeneration of the sulphide sites, and prolong catalyst life [41]. However, Krause's group showed that, in the presence of H2S, thiols were generated during methyl heptanoate HDO over the sulfided Co-Mo/Al2O3 at 250 °C and 15 bar H2 [48]. Incorporating sulphur into the product stream increases the potential to generate toxic exhaust gases, such as SOx, during biofuels combustion. While H2S can also exist in gaseous products streams, therefore additional processing of reaction exhaust gases is necessary. Non-sulphide systems which combined Mo or W and first-row transition metals (e.g. Ni and Cu) have also been explored for HDO [49–52] and can promote HDO reactions under similar conditions as sulphide catalysts (∼320 °C). These non-sulphide catalysts usually require precise control over the catalyst support structure and metal dispersion. For example, Yan et al. used phyllosilicate to confine nickel nanoparticles, whilst Duan et al. incorporated Mo within crystalline ZrO2, which resulted in the transfer from a cubic to a monoclinic structure [49,50]. Overall, HDO processes using sulphide catalysts are only possible under harsh operating conditions with co-feeding of sulphide auxiliaries, and hence process economics and environmental impact are far from ideal. 2.2 Carbide and nitride catalysts Carbides and nitrides of early transition metals (Group III to VII) are also effective HDO catalysts, as shown in Table 2 , with activity similar to sulphide equivalents [53]. CH4/H2 and ammonia are often employed to carburise and nitride transition metals, respectively, typically at temperatures greater than 700 °C [30]. Furimsky et al. demonstrated that Group VI metals have lower enthalpies of formation (<42 kJ/mole) during carburisation in comparison with Group V metal (>75.6 kJ/mole) and Group IV metals (>168 kJ/mole) [53]. Hence, the carbides of Group VI metals, such as Mo2C and WC, are shown to possess great stability [54]. Crystallographic structures of Mo2C, Mo2N, and MoS2 are presented in Fig. 3 [28], showing that Mo2C and Mo2N present as metallic interstitial alloys of C or N, with hexagonal close-packed or body-centred cubic structure, respectively, whilst MoS2 forms an insulating layered structure. The relatively smaller atomic radii of C and N allows them to nest in interstices of the lattice of Mo [53], with Mo2C and Mo2N exhibiting metal like characteristics including high stability. Monnier et al. prepared Mo2N supported on γ-Al2O3 and evaluated the catalyst in canola oil HDO at 400 °C and 83.5 bar H2, which demonstrated a high and stable oxygen rejection rate of >90 % over a 450 h period [29]. More critically, carbide and nitride catalysts do not require continuous sulfidation to maintain the activity. The incorporation of carbon or nitrogen into group VI metals can impart functionality similar to noble metals, i.e. the ability to activate hydrogen [53,58]. As a result, Mo2C and Mo2N display catalytic activity for HDO [29,59]. Han et al. studied HDO of olive oil over Mo2C/active carbon [55]. TPR demonstrated H2 activation on the surface of Mo2C at 280 °C, which promoted the HDO performance of 94 % conversion with a 57.6 % yield of C16–C18 after the 4 h reaction in batch. In addition, deficiencies in C and N content can result in supplementary oxygen incorporation to form oxycarbides and oxynitrides. This beneficially introduces acidic sites to promote catalytic alcohol dehydration [58]. For instance, Ren et al. carried out HDO of propanol over tungsten monocarbide at 380 °C and showed an enhancement in alcohol deoxygenation to alkenes. This is in line with density functional theory simulations and ultrahigh vacuum studies on model catalysts surfaces, and suggests the in-situ generation of a surface oxycarbide species [60]. To further enhance hydrogen activation over Mo carbides and nitrides, Ni has been employed as a promoter [3]. Wang et al. investigated Ni loading effects on Mo2C/ZSM-5 catalyst performance in HDO of soybean oil (at 400 °C and 44 bar H2) [61]. Over the pristine Mo2C/ZSM-5 catalyst, severe deactivation was measured after three days due to the formation of heavy hydrocarbons (>C23), whereas the Ni doped catalyst (Ni:Mo molar ratio = 1.5) demonstrated enhanced stability over 7 days. However, this was accompanied by the increased production of gaseous species (C1–C4), from 5 % to 40 %, suggesting that Ni also promoted hydrocracking under the conditions used. The conventional preparation route for bimetallic carbide or nitride catalysts consists of impregnating a catalyst support with metal salt precursors, calcination to obtain metal oxides, and carburisation or nitridation to yield the final catalysts. However, during calcination, the formation of alloys is likely. This alloying is both irreversible and undesirable from the perspective of catalyst performance. To combat this, Alwan et al. prepared the NiWC/Al-SBA-15 catalyst by loading pre-reduced tungsten nanoparticles on the Ni/Al-SBA-15 catalyst [56]. During HDO of corn oil at 400 °C and 44 bar, the NiWC/Al-SBA-15 catalyst presented significantly improved performance with 100 % conversion and stability over 23 days, a significant improvement on the counterpart catalyst prepared by the conventional protocol (conversion ∼ 23.4 %). Aside from early transition metals, Fe based catalysts have also been investigated. Li et al. prepared the Fe catalyst supported on a hybrid nitrogen-doped carbon-alumina (Fe-N-C) for HDO of stearic acid at 320 °C and 40 bar [57]. Melamine, the nitrogen precursor, prevented unwanted hercynite (FeAl₂O₄) formation while imparting Lewis basicity, which facilitated the adsorption of acidic substrates. In addition, considering the potential of Fe-N-C based materials for electrocatalytic hydrogen activation [57], the exploitation of electrocatalysts in HDO may deserve further investigation. 2.3 Noble metal catalysts Pd or Pt, supported on neutral (e.g. carbon), acidic (e.g. Al2O3 and zeolites) or reducible supports (e.g. TiO2 and ZrO2), are all active towards HDO. Both the metal and supports play essential roles in the system, i.e. the noble metal allows for adsorption and dissociation of H2, while the choice of the catalyst supports can influence reaction pathways that proceed, as shown in Eqs. 2–6. Here we review Pd and Pt catalysts supported on various supports for HDO, focusing on the factors that govern the dominant reaction route. To facilitate direct comparison, normalised activities (as per Eq. 7) were calculated and are shown in Table 3 . (7) N o r m a l i s e r e a c t i o n r a t e = m a s s o f f e e d s t o c k × c o n v e r s i o n m a s s o f c a t a l y s t × m e t a l l o a d i n g × t i m e Carbon materials, including graphite [38], activated carbon (AC) [64], and carbon black [62] are common neutral catalyst supports. Simakova et al. used precipitation-deposition to load Pd on sibunit (a type of carbon black) for deoxygenation of stearic acid at 280 °C and 17.5 bar of 5 vol.% H2 in Ar [62]. The selectivity to the DCOx product, i.e. heptadecane, was almost 100 % and the normalised reaction activity was calculated as 992 h−1. Although the catalyst was only selective to DCOx, the reaction conditions are milder than those required by sulphide catalysts, with significantly reduced H2 pressure. Likewise, Sousa et al. study HDO over a commercial Pd/AC (Aldrich) for palmist oil at 300 °C and 10 bar H2 [63]. In contrast, Arvela et al. conducted decarboxylation (DCO2) of lauric acid using a commercial Pd/AC (Aldrich) in the absence of H2 [64]. Under N2 at 300 °C and 13 bar, the system's normalised rate is only 2.2 h−1 with 99 % selectivity to C11 hydrocarbon, but the ability to produce hydrocarbon under inert conditions is an exciting prospect. Pd on carbon, is, therefore, a competent DCOx catalyst in the presence or absence of H2, although activity without H2 is dramatically lower. The capacity of Pd/C for DCO2 can be attributed to the non-polar surface of Pd, which favours adsorption of the alkyl chain, leading to CC bond cleavage, as illustrated in Fig. 4 [8]. So, while DCO2 is favoured in the absence of hydrogen over Pd sites [8], the addition of H2 switches the pathway to decarbonylation (DCO) [73]. Therefore, although carbon-based catalytic systems could reduce hydrogen consumption, they led to equimolar CO2/CO emissions [21]. In addition, the use of neutral supports does not appear to favour alkane isomerisation. Inherent support acidity, either Brønsted or Lewis, can impart noteworthy influence on HDO selectivity. Specifically, Brønsted acidity can impede DCO by promoting dehydration, whilst carbonyl groups can be activated at Lewis acid sites to promote HDO. γ-Al2O3, with its mild acidity derived from tetrahedral framework aluminium, is commonly applied for high temperature HDO due to its low tendency towards undesirable hydrocracking side-reactions [75]. Kim and co-workers prepared a range of metals on γ-Al2O3 catalysts for HDO of soybean oil under the batch condition (at 400 °C and 92 bar) [65]. The comparative catalytic assessment showed that the performance regarding soybean oil conversion followed the order of sulfided NiMo/γ-Al2O3 (92.9 %) > Pd/γ-Al2O3 (91.9 %) > Pt/γ-Al2O3 (50.8 %) > Ru/γ-Al2O3 (39.7 %) with >90 % selectivity to diesel range hydrocarbons in all catalytic systems. Pd/γ-Al2O3 and sulfided NiMo/γ-Al2O3 exhibited comparable optimal activity and selectivity, with the extreme reaction temperature enabling rapid conversion (reaction times of only 2 h). The C17 to C18 product ratio (C17:C18) revealed the dominant reaction pathways. Specifically, a ratio of 11.9 for Pd/γ-Al2O3 is indicative of DCOx, whereas the sulfided NiMo/γ-Al2O3 showed a low value of 2.49, revealing that HDO was promoted. These observations are reflected in the gaseous products observed, as shown in Fig. 5 [65]. Pd/γ-Al2O3 has also been reported for HDO of stearic acid at 350 °C and 14 bar and showed almost identical selectivity (91 %) to C17 hydrocarbons [66]. Pd, therefore, appears to favour DCOx over HDO. In contrast, the Pt/γ-Al2O3 system showed a C17:C18 value of 0.92, suggesting that, over Pt, HDO and DCOx occurred simultaneously with comparable rates, reflecting the significant influence of metal choice on reaction pathways in HDO [65]. By comparing Pt with Pd, the Pauling electronegativity of Pt (2.28) is higher than that of Pd (2.20), suggesting the improved interaction between the Pt site with the carbonyl group of the fatty acid, and hence promoting the HDO pathway [76]. Accordingly, to suppress DCOx routes, the adsorption of substrates on the metal sites requires careful consideration to promote carbonyl adsorption rather than alkyl chain interaction. The incorporation of Al species within mesoporous silica frameworks, such as SBA-15 to generate Al-SBA-15 [77], provides a facile synthetic route to high surface area mesoporous acidic supports, i.e. ∼800 m2 g−1 vs ∼200 m2 g−1 for γ-Al2O3 [65,67]. An increase in support surface area was anticipated to improve noble metal dispersion, which was proposed to reduce alkyl adsorption on the metal site due to steric effects, with similar observation reported over Pd/ZLT [70]. Furthermore, the acidity of Al-SBA-15 is tuneable through the concentration of Al species incorporated. To date, HDO over Al-SBA-15 based catalysts have been investigated to comprehend the effect of the support acidity on selectivity. Pd doped Al-SBA-15, with varied silicon-to-aluminium ratios (SAR) of 38 and 152, revealed HDO to be favoured at lower SAR, while activity was also increased (108 h−1 vs 83 h−1) [67]. Increasing SAR generates higher acidity, with acid site density of 0.149 mmol g−1 vs 0.066 mmol g−1 for SAR of 38 and 152. The authors proposed Lewis acids, based on 27Al MAS NMR analysis (Fig. 6 ). However, pyridine adsorption studies have shown that Al-SBA-15 (synthesised via a true liquid-crystal templating method) can possess both Lewis and Brønsted acidity [78,79]. The effect of SAR of Al-SBA-15 catalysts on HDO was further confirmed by Duan et al. [68]. In the work, the Pd/Al-SBA-15 catalysts were prepared from supports with SAR values of 22–300 for HDO of stearic acid at 250 °C and 20 bar of H2, and the catalytic results showed that a decrease in the SAR of the Al-SBA-15 support (from 300 to 22) caused an increase in the yield of C18 hydrocarbons (from ∼20 % to ∼46 %), confirming the positive effect of acidity within Al-SBA-15 on selectivity towards HDO products. Zeolites are microporous crystalline aluminosilicates, with significant Brønsted acidity arising from the Si-O(H)-Al groups in their frameworks [80], which can have a positive influence on suppressing DCO during HDO [45]. Murata et al. investigated HDO of jatropha oil (mainly C16 and C18 fatty acids) over Pt/HZSM-5 and Pt/USY at 270 °C and 65 bar of H2 [35]. Pt/HZSM-5 showed a normalised reaction rate of 8.3 h−1 with 59.3 % selectivity towards the HDO products, whereas Pt/USY was less active and selective with values of 2.6 h−1 and 44 %. Notably, Pt/USY also promoted the formation of C19+ hydrocarbons (selectivity at around 19.1 %), which was due to esterification between the fatty acid starting substrate and the fatty alcohol intermediate product. This pathway is attributed to the weaker acidity of USY, as compared with ZSM-5, i.e. Si-O(H)-Al angle: 138–147° for USY vs. 133–177° for ZSM-5 [81]. An increased Si-O-Al angle represents high hybridisation of the oxygen atom electrons, which results in stronger acidity and subsequent increased activity towards alcohol dehydration. Therefore, ZSM-5 is able to convert (dehydrate) the fatty alcohol intermediate more rapidly, and thus esterification is less favourable. In HDO of oleic acid over Pd/ZLT, the improved Pd dispersion and reduced Pd particle sizes also resulted in the enhanced HDO selectivity [69]. The strong Si-O-Pd bonds improved Pd dispersion and suppressed the yield of C17H36 to < 5 %. Interestingly, in addition to a 56 % yield of n-C18H38, iso-C18H38 was also produced (11 % yield), potentially providing a route to produce low freezing point biofuels. By varying the pH during Pd doping, the pore diameter of the ZLT zeolite (enlarged) and Pd particle sizes (reduced) were successfully engineered, which in turn benefited HDO selectivity, especially the yield of iso-C18H38 [82]. It should be noted that zeolites can also possess Lewis acidity, generated by dislodging Al from the original zeolite framework, with extra-framework alumina forming an octahedral structure with Lewis acidity [83], however, to date, insight into the role of Lewis acidity in zeolites on HDO is lacking. Reducible metal oxide supports represent another class of materials employed for the preparation of HDO catalysts. Their ability to be partially reduced under H2 (or more explicitly reducing conditions) can introduce vacancies and Lewis acidity. HDO of palmitic acid over Pt/ZrO2 has been reported, showing HDO selectivity to the alcohol only, i.e. palmityl alcohol at about 28.5 % without full HDO products (alkane/alkene) [71], with esterification and DCOx pathways also apparent. Pt/SnO2 has shown performance for a series of linear fatty acids under a mild condition at 200 °C and 8 bar of H2 [72]. Again, this only enabled partial HDO together with esterification reactions. Hardacre and co-workers deployed a 4 wt.% Pt/TiO2 catalyst for HDO of a series of carboxylic acid (C2–C4) at 145–200 °C [84]. An increase in substrate molecular weight inhibited esterification, whereas increasing temperatures could promote esterification. 4 wt.% Pt/TiO2 has also been used in HDO of stearic acid with high selectivity towards the fatty alcohol was observed under very mild conditions (130 °C) [73]. The high selectivity of the catalysts based on reducible oxides to alcohol/ester products can be attributed to the supports' relatively weak acidity, which hinders/eliminates alcohol dehydration and fallows for esterification [72]. One upshot of catalysts based on reducible supports is the suppression of the DCOx pathway, albeit under relatively mild conditions. Hence, further investigation into the influence of catalyst design and reaction conditions, in particular temperature, on HDO selectivity over reducible metal oxide supported catalysts is necessary. Similar to the catalysts based on reducible metal oxides, systems employing solid base supports also present relatively low HDO activity for activating the fatty alcohol intermediate. Setyoningsih et al. compared Ru catalysts supported on MgO and Al2O3 for HDO of stearic acid (at 300 °C and 40 bar), with the MgO system obtaining only 8 % alkane yield compared to 34.4 % over Ru/γ-Al2O3 [85]. Furthermore, DCO was preferred during the reaction even at relatively low temperatures due to the strong interaction between the basic supports and acidic functional group, which promoted CC dissociation/hydrogenolysis [73,74]. Recently, Ru supported on basic hydroxyapatite (HAP) was developed for HDO of stearic acid. The role of solvent was shown to be critical on C17:C18, with neat hexane promoting DCOx pathways and 90 % water/hexane mixture (90/10 v/v) promoting HDO [74]. This could be attributed to the presence of calcium vacancy sites within HAP, which provided sites for water dissociation to produce H free radicals. In summary, the state-of-the-art HDO catalysts play roles in both hydrogen activation and selective adsorption of fatty acid. However, to encourage alkane production, the catalyst support acidity and metal particle dispersion need to be engineered rationally. Currently, the single metal HDO catalysts are usually active at temperatures >280 °C which commonly results in relatively low selectivity to HDO products. 3 Low-temperature HDO catalysts To improve the HDO activity and allow the reaction to proceed under milder conditions, promoters are commonly used to dope noble metal catalysts, as shown in Table 4 . Rhenium (Re) is a common promoter for HDO catalysts and can reduce reaction temperature to <200 °C. The function of Re is generally explained by its oxyphilicity, which enhances the interaction between the catalyst and the lone pair of electrons on the carbonyl [73]. Takeda et al. doped ReOx on Pd/SiO2 (Re/Pd molar ratio = 8) to promote HDO of stearic acid [86]. The pristine 1 wt.% Pd/SiO2 catalyst showed no HDO activity at 140 °C, whereas ReOx-Pd/SiO2 catalyst was active, with a normalised reaction rate of 113 h−1 and 96.6 % selectivity to C18 alcohol. The doped catalyst was also considerably more active than ReOx/SiO2 and a ReOx/SiO2 + Pd/SiO2 physical mixture, which showed activities of 1.7 and 58 h−1, respectively. As evidenced by H2-TPR analysis, in ReOx-Pd/SiO2, the valence of the Re phase was increased to 4.5 instead of 2.0, suggesting an interaction between Pd and Re. Further characterisation of the ReOx-Pd/SiO2 catalyst was performed to understand the Re and Pd phase synergy [91]. XANES and XPS revealed Re oxidation states, suggesting the importance of Re +3 and +4 oxidation states for promoting HDO, while CO chemisorption identified Re cations covering the Re and Pd nanoparticles. Accordingly, it was concluded that Pd improved the dispersion of Re species, allowing the existence of Re cations (as shown in Fig. 7 ), which in turn led to the enhanced catalytic HDO activity. The influence of Re doping of Pt on TiO2 for low temperature stearic acid HDO (at 130 °C) was investigated by Hardacre and co-workers [73], who showed that 4 wt.% Re doping caused a more than a 2-fold increase in the normalised activity, but this was at the expense of selectivity, which drops by about 22 % in comparison with Pt/TiO2. The improvement in acid conversion was likewise attributed to the interaction between the carbonyl group and Re cations. In contrast, the decrease of HDO selectivity was ascribed to the interaction between Re and the hydroxyl group of the acid, facilitating DCO2. Further comparative investigation of the Pt/TiO2, Re/TiO2, Pt-Re/TiO2 catalysts for HDO of acetic acid was carried out at 200 °C and 40 bar H2, revealing that Pt was responsible for H2 dissociation, while Re enabled the HDO [84]. A similar mechanism was also proposed by Liu et al. for HDO of palm oil over the Ir-ReOx/SiO2 catalysts, in which Ir activated H2 and partially reduced ReOx. The latter weakened the carbonyl functional groups of the carboxylic acid and ester [87]. To promote alcohol dehydration to alkenes, the use of an acidic co-catalyst, namely HZSM-5, was proposed. It should be noted that Ir-ReOx exhibits unique catalytic activity in CO bonds hydrogenolysis while simultaneously impeding CC bond hydrogenolysis [92]. Rhenium has also been shown to promote palladium phases supported on neutral supports. Pd-Re/graphite shows a high capacity for fatty alcohol formation at 130 °C and alkane formation at 160 °C, with complete suppression of DCO2 [38]. Ullrich et al. monitored product evolution during octanoic acid HDO over Pd-Re/graphite at 160 °C and 30 bar, as shown in Fig. 8 a. Only when the acid was entirely consumed at 2 h did the yield of alkane increased significantly, with full conversion of the alcohol (to the alkane) achieved in 6 h. The authors suggested that the acid substrate inhibits alcohol dehydration, potentially reflecting the interaction of the carbonyl of the acid with Re, and hence alkane production could only proceed upon the full conversion of acid to alcohol. The reaction also contained an amount of 4A molecular sieve, which has been shown to catalyse ethanol dehydration, albeit at an elevated temperature of 270 °C [39]. Therefore, one could also speculate that full HDO may actually occur in a cascade manner over two distinct sites, that is, site 1 (Pd-Re/graphite) for fatty acid reduction to the alcohol, and site 2 (zeolite) for alcohol dehydration. The resulting alkene could then be hydrogenated rapidly to the alkane over the Pd-Re/graphite site. In a similar manner, Guo et al. used a physical mixture of Pd/CuZnAl and ZSM-5 (SAR = 25) for HDO of methyl decanoate at 200 °C and 20 bar. They showed in the presence of the Pd catalyst only, HDO halted at the alcohol, and the addition of zeolite was critical to driving HDO towards completion, as depicted in Fig. 8b [40]. Findings of this work showed that the combination of supported noble metal catalysts and acidic zeolites could ensure the efficient and effective HDO of acids to alkanes. (8) 7 Pd- H ads + Re O 4 − + H + → R e 0 ( Pd ) 7 + 4 H 2 O Wet impregnation methods are often employed for preparing Re doped HDO catalysts, with Re loading commonly at 4 wt.% or above [38,73]. Conversely, surface redox methods provide a highly effective pathway to achieve effective low loading of Re phases. Ly et al. prepared Pd-Re/TiO2 catalysts by loading Re over Pd/TiO2 using surface redox method in an acidic environment (as per Eq. (8) [93]. Hydrogenation of γ-butyrolactone to 1,4-butanediol at 160 °C was conducted over 2.2 wt.% Pd-0.8 wt.% Re/TiO2 (by surface redox method) and 2.2 wt.% Pd-3.4 wt.% Re/TiO2 (by impregnation). After 30 h, the surface redox prepared catalyst outperformed the conventional impregnated materials by approximately 60 % [91,94]. However, surface redox synthesis protocols are more complex and require an acidic pH, which possibly limits the choice of catalyst supports. An inherent concern that requires consideration when looking to deploy ReOx as the dopant is its sublimation temperature of ∼450 °C [95], and may be considerably lower for highly dispersed Re species. HDO promotion by Lewis acids is also known and arises via the activation of the carbonyl group [72]. Shao et al. introduced 10 wt.% Nb2O5 into 4 wt.% Pd/SiO2 for catalysing HDO of palmitic acid (at 170 °C and 25 bar) [88]. The normalised reaction rate and final selectivity to C16 alkane were 3 h−1 and ∼90 %, respectively, thus HDO was favoured. Hexadecanol yield initially increased to ∼60 % over the first 3 h, but then subsequently decreased to only ∼8 % in the following 5 h due to dehydration (to C16 alkene), probably over the moderate strength acid sites of Nb2O5, as compared with the acidity of zeolites [38]. It is also worth noting that Nb2O5 doped Pd/SiO2 showed exceptional stability, being able to be recycled for 5 times without significant losses of activity (>90 % conversion in each recycle). Kon et al. likewise investigated the interaction between Pt and Nb2O5 within a Pt/Nb2O5 catalysts and identified a suboxide (NbOx) layer on Pt by CO chemisorption analysis, as illustrated in Fig. 9 [36]. Based on in-situ IR characterisation of the catalysis, charge transfer from the carbonyl group (Lewis base) to NbOx (Lewis acid) was suggested, being responsible for adsorption carbonyl group. MoOx has also been deployed as a Lewis acid promotor, with modified Pt/TiO2 developed for HDO of stearic acid at 230 °C [72]. An In-situ FT-IR spectroscopy study of acetone adsorption (Fig. 10 ) revealed the carbonyl group quickly coordinates with MoOx (Lewis acid sites). This, combined with the HDO performance, led to the proposal that the Lewis acid sites impart the ability to activate the carbonyl group, thus promoting HDO of fatty acids at low temperatures. However, as shown in Table 4, the catalysts based on MoOx and Nb2O5 have relatively low alkane production activity. Hence, further development of HDO catalysts for converting fatty acids under mild conditions is still a challenge. 4 Mechanisms for HDO of fatty acids in catalytic systems employing zeolites As discussed above, to realise HDO of fatty acid at <200 °C, noble metals can facilitate H2 dissociate with a second metal (promoter) enabling carbonyl group activation. Nb and Mo oxides can be used as promoters to produce alkanes, however, they are hindered by low promoting performance especially relative to ReOx, which can impart tens of times higher performance (Table 4) but at the expense of the reaction terminating at the fatty alcohols. One strategy to enable the use of ReOx promotors is to incorporate dehydration sites to convert the alcohol to an alkene rapidly. This, in turn, should allow the avoidance of esterification reaction between the reactively formed alcohol and unreacted carboxylic acid. With relatively strong acidity, zeolites are one example of a solid acid that can impart this beneficial dehydration, converting fatty alcohols into alkenes. The resulting olefin can then further react over the original noble metal site, via hydrogenation, to produce desired alkanes. Accordingly, zeolites can be used as either catalyst supports or additives to develop low temperature catalytic HDO systems for alkane production [38,40,45]. As alluded in the discussion above, fatty acids (such as stearic acid (C18)) under HDO conditions can undergo a variety of reactions, with the catalyst properties influencing the reaction pathways greatly. The spectrum of possible catalytic pathways is illustrated in Fig. 11 [45]. For instance, Pd/C can catalyse direct decarboxylation of fatty acid, even in the absence of H2 (blue region) [64], while Re doped Pt on TiO2 can induce the reduction of stearic acid to the C18 alcohol, which can be further dehydrated into alkene if acidic sites, such as zeolites (red region), are present [38], representing complete acid HDO. Alternatively, when alcohol dehydration does not proceed, either dehydrogenation to stearyl aldehyde (yellow region), usually over mild acidic or neutral catalyst supports [45], or esterification via reaction with the starting fatty acid (grey region) can occur. In the case of the former, fatty aldehydes are generally unstable under these conditions and frequently decarbonylate to C17 alkane and CO [75]. 4.1 Identification of an alternative reaction route Complete HDO of fatty acid, via the reduction (yellow route) and dehydration/hydrogenation (red route), represents a favourable HDO pathway, due to the avoidance of CO/CO2 generation, and thus greater atom-efficient and environmental benefit. He et al. proposed the mechanisms of partial fatty acid HDO to the aldehyde over noble metal catalysts, as shown in Fig. 12 [96]. When inert supports such as silica or carbon are employed, as shown in mechanism (a), the fatty acid is adsorbed and activated on either noble metal sites or metal-support interface through exposed cations vacancies. At the same time, hydrogen is dissociated over noble metal sites, which attacks CO bond. In contrast, over reducible supports, including TiO2, MoO3 and SnO2, as shown in mechanism (b), oxygen vacancies can be generated through surface oxygen reactions with H2 [96]. The carbonyl group of the fatty acid can adsorb at these vacancies, where they undergo CO cleavage. As with inert supports, the noble metal promotes hydrogen dissociation, which spills over on to the support. Subsequent aldehyde reduction appears to proceed rapidly without desorbing, as aldehyde products are not detected [97]. In addition to the reducible supports, mechanism (b) also occurs when using Re and Lewis acid promotors, with the carbonyl functionality interacting with Re or Lewis acid sites [38,72]. Relative to mechanism (a), mechanism (b) can proceed at significantly lower temperatures, from ∼280 °C to less than 200 °C [96], and thus appear to be highly beneficial to developing low-temperature HDO processes. HDO of the fatty alcohol intermediate is required if complete HDO is to be achieved, with alcohol dehydration to alkenes, commonly realised with zeolites as supports or additives, in particular when reaction temperature exceeds 300 °C. Fig. 13 shows the mechanism of ethanol dehydration over zeolites, disclosing both monomolecular decomposition and bimolecular ether forming dehydration pathways [41]. For the decomposition route, ethanol is adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites, which dehydrates to generate a surface ethoxide. Proton transfer regenerates the Brønsted acid site and liberates the alkene product. The second route also proceeds via ethanol adsorption on a Brønsted site, however, a second ethanol molecule is co-adsorbed at the same Brønsted acid site, which then dehydrates into diethyl ether. Chiang et al. conducted kinetic studies on ethanol dehydration over acidic zeolites and found that the rate constant for activation for the co-adsorbed route is proportional to pore size [98], thus smaller pore sizes might impart superior performance during fatty alcohol dehydration. The final step of this multi-step pathway, to yield the desired alkane, is the hydrogenation of alkene dehydration product, which can occur over the initial noble metal sites. The final step can be expected to be rapid under the reaction conditions (at high temperature and hydrogen pressures), with alkene products only detected at the initial stage of reaction and in small quantities [10]. Furthermore, acidic zeolites can also induce isomerisation to produces iso-alkanes, however, isomerisation reactions usually require a temperature range of 260–320 °C rather than under mild reaction conditions (i.e. at < 200 °C) proposed during the multi-step HDO cascade [99–101]. Zeolites with strong acidity can effectively promote isomerisation at reduced temperatures, with Batalha et al. demonstrating the conversion of n-hexadecane to iso-hexadecane (with 95 % selectivity) at only 220 °C over 1 wt.% Pt/H-Beta (SAR = 16), although undesirable hydrocracking accounted for the remaining selectivity [102]. Further decreasing the SAR to 11, resulted in increasing hydrocracking products selectivity due to the higher Brønsted acid concentration. A scheme for low-temperature HDO over noble metal functionalised zeolites is presented in Fig. 14 . The proposed catalyst design should provide a route (Scheme 1) for fatty acid HDO to hydrocarbon biofuel via total HDO, with only water as the side product. However, under HDO conditions, consecutive and parallel side-reactions can occur. Accordingly, it is critical to understand the conditions and catalytic species that can lead to these, and thus how to avoid them to a large extent. 4.2 Side reactions DCO2 DCO2 can be enabled when the alkyl group of fatty acid adsorbs on the noble metal surface, as shown in Fig. 4. Therefore, to avoid DCO2, the substrate absorption mode during HDO is the key, which can be tuned by engineering the catalyst, the support, and promoters. For example, supports with strong Brønsted acidity such as zeolites can potentially inhibit the dissociation of fatty acids. Whereas reaction conditions, especially temperature, have shown relative insignificance on selectivity towards DCO2 [8,97,103]. However, high temperatures in HDO are prone to cause the formation of other by-products such as short-chain (C4–C7) and/or aromatic hydrocarbons (via thermal decomposition and aromatisation) in HDO of vegetable oil at >350 °C [103]. DCO The aldehyde intermediate of fatty acid HDO is relatively unstable, which can either undergo reversible reduction into fatty alcohol or irreversibly DCO to form Cn−1 hydrocarbons. The DCO process is more common over unpromoted noble metal sites (Table 3), and in the case of Pt, Re doping does not entirely turn off DCO [73]. Kumar et al. found that catalysts with dehydration capability can inhibit the DCO route, via rapid conversion of alcohols [45]. For example, Ni/ZSM-5 has been used to catalyse HDO of stearic acid with 61.1 % selectivity to C18 hydrocarbon, whereas a Ni/SiO2 catalyst, which is not active for alcohol dehydration, results in 76.6 % C17 hydrocarbon selectivity. Chen et al. investigated HDO of methyl stearate over Ru/ZSM-5 at 220 °C in water and cyclohexane, respectively, which showed different selectivity towards Cn−1 hydrocarbons, i.e. ∼83 % in water vs ∼63 % in cyclohexane [97]. The difference in selectivity was ascribed to the strong suppression of alcohol dehydration by water. Thus, more fatty aldehyde was present in the reaction mixture, and greater DCO was encouraged. However, this contrasts with what has been observed for Ru/HAP, in which water promoted HDO [74]. Therefore, both catalyst and reaction conditions need to be adjusted to favour alcohol dehydration if selectivity to Cn−1 hydrocarbons in final products is minimised. Biofuels provide pathways to transportation fuels which can mitigate greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and, currently, can be produced through Fischer-Tropsch (FT), transesterification and hydro-treating (a mix of HDO and DCOx) [104,105]. Kalnes et al. conducted Life-cycle Analysis (LCA) on biodiesel and green diesel production. They showed that hydro-treating could potentially reduce GHG emissions by 50 % relative to FT and 19 % relative to transesterification, when calculated per ton of biomass feedstock [105]. In contrast, LCA by Arun, which was evaluated on the production of 1 l of fuel, showed CO2 emissions were 25 % higher for hydro-treating as compared to biodiesel (transesterification) [106]. It should be noted that CO2 emissions from hydro-treating processing are highly dependent on the assumptions used for heat supply, and hydrogen provision, whilst the reaction route selectivity in HDO or DCOx is also critical. Typically, energy (heat) production is based on non-renewables, while H2 production is assumed to arise from steam reforming of natural gas [14]. However, the current drive to renewable energy and sustainable chemical production, including hydrogen, should decrease contributions from these [106], and thus improve the LCA performance of hydro-treating. Regarding process pathway selectivity, HDO vs DCOx, while DCOX would appear to represent significant benefits on H2 consumption, secondary reactions of the gaseous by-products (water gas shift and methanisation) are common at typical DCOx temperature (> 300 °C) [10,107]. These can result in significant H2 consumption [108]. Where side reactions are prohibited, carbon capture and storage are ideal for cleaning up the gaseous waste stream, however, storage capacity and social acceptance needs to be addressed [109,110]. Specifically, the storage capacity of fossil-fuel reservoirs is rather limited, thus CO2 need to be stored in coal-beds, saline aquifers and even ocean, which may not be safe [109]. Alternatively, a highly selective low temperature HDO pathway, as set out within this contribution, would overcome any requirement for carbon capture, via switching off of DCOx process pathway, while simultaneously impacting positively on energy requirements. However, a fair evaluation of HDO and DCOx is only feasible via LCA analysis of the two, unfortunately, to the best of the author knowledge this is lacking in the current literature. 4.3 Esterification, cracking and coking While acidic supports such as zeolites can induce dehydration, acid sites may also promote esterification between fatty alcohol intermediate and fatty acid substrate, leading to the formation of high boiling/melting point esters. While esters can be considered as biofuels, they are more commonly produced deliberately via transesterification with short-chain alcohols, e.g. FAME (biodiesels). Such esters represent lower value products relative to potential aviation biofuels. Furthermore, production routes to bio-derived aviation fuels can be considered more pressing, as they can meet the demands of a transportation sector that cannot be addressed readily by alternative energy vectors (such as batteries or hydrogen). Therefore, esters in this context are perceived as by-products of fatty acid HDO. Murata et al. carried out HDO of jatropha oil (mainly C18 fatty acid) over Pt/ZSM-5 catalysts (at 270 °C and 65 bar), which showed nearly 30 % selectivity towards C19+ compounds [35]. However, when Pt-Re/ZSM-5 was used under the same condition, the yield to C19+ hydrocarbon reduced to ∼5 %, indicating that Re impedes esterification. He et al. proposed that when fatty acids adsorbed on metal sites with Brønsted acid sites in close proximity, carbocation formation is likely, which can induce esterification or even direct coking [96]. The role of Re in Pt-Re/ZSM-5 may well influence the adsorption on the metal surface at 270 °C and inhibit interaction with Brønsted acid sites in the zeolite. Baharudin et al. found acid sites in Ni/Al-SBA-15 promoted ester production (∼70 % selectivity) during the initial stage of HDO of octanoic acid (within 30 min.). However, the ester is subsequently depleted, via hydrogenolysis or hydrolysis, to <5 % at 3 h (with 86 % yield of C8 alkane), once condition favourable to ester formation are overcome [111]. Therefore, this identifies an alternative strategy to deal with unwanted esterification side reactions by imparting catalytic capacity to convert ester back into their constituent alcohols and carboxylic acids. Cracking and coking represent irreversible decomposition reactions, with cracking producing short-chain alkanes which would be of specification for desired biofuels, while coking can deactivate catalysts through pore blockage and active site poisoning. To reduce these undesired reactions, both zeolite acidity and reaction temperature are significant factors. Fortunately, HDO of fatty acids is viable at mild condition (<200 °C), where coking and cracking can be suppressed [96]. 5 Conclusion In this review, we performed a critical discussion of different classes of catalysts for HDO of fatty acids. Although conventional HDO catalysts have relative high activity for yielding hydrocarbons, the associated environmental issues and energy intensity reduce their attractiveness. To operate HDO under milder conditions (<200 °C), noble metals are required to dissociate H2 while promotors, such as MoOx, Nb2O5 and Re, are used to activate the carbonyl group in fatty acids. Zeolites with suitable Brønsted acidity can be introduced into HDO catalytic systems to promote the dehydration of the fatty alcohol intermediate (partial HDO) and the yield hydrocarbons (complete HDO). This systematic and critical comparison of the various types of HDO catalysts gives a comprehensive insight into the function of different active sites, promotors and supports. This should provide a guide for future developments in HDO catalysis, especially the design of novel multifunctional catalysts for the sustainable production of biofuels via low temperature HDO. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) provides a promising route for upgrading biomass-derived fatty acids to alkanes, which are potential biofuels (e.g. jet fuel (C8–C16) and diesel (C12–C22)) that could reduce our reliance on unsustainable fossil fuels. Currently, catalytic HDO, conducted over catalysts such as molybdenum disulfide, necessitates harsh operating conditions (>300 °C) which is both environmentally and economically unsustainable and promotes unwanted side reactions, e.g. cracking, which compromises product selectivity. Accordingly, the development of novel catalysts, which enable efficient and sustainable HDO, under milder operating conditions, and their translation from lab bench to large-scale production are highly desired. This review discusses the recent development of heterogeneous catalysts for HDO (including reaction pathways, mechanisms, and side reactions) and explores design strategies for the development of new multifunctional catalysts with potential to enable future development of HDO processes under mild conditions. In particular, we consider the sequential cascade transformation of fatty acids into fatty alcohols (via hydrodeoxygenation) and then hydrocarbons (via dehydration and hydrogenation), which requires the coupling of different but complementary catalytic sites, as an attractive alternative mild HDO strategy.
coredata.dc:title: Recent developments in multifunctional catalysts for fatty acid hydrodeoxygenation as a route towards biofuels
